trans: This year Ceawlin and Cutha fought with the Britons on the spot that is called Fretherne. There Cutha was slain. And Ceawlin took many towns, as well as immense booty and wealth. He then retreated to his own people. This year died King Ella; and Ethelric reigned after him five years.

context: And her æðelfrið #lædde# his færde to Legercyestre , \& ðar| of sloh unrim Walena ․| \& swa wearð gefyld Augustinus witegunge ․ þe he cwæð ․ Gif| Wealas nellað sibbe wið us ․ hi sculan æt Seaxana| handa farwurþan ․| þar man sloh eac cc preosta ða comon ðyder þæt hi| scoldon gebiddan for Walena here ․| Scrocmail was gehaten heora ealdormann ․ se atbærst ðanon| fiftiga sum .
trans: And this year Ethelfrith led his army to Chester; where he slew an innumerable host of the Welsh; And so was fulfilled the prophecy of Augustine, wherein he saith: ‘If the Welsh will not have peace with us, they shall perish at the hands of the Saxons.’ There were also slain two hundred priests, who came thither to pray for the army of the Welsh. Their leader was called Brocmail who with some fifty men escaped thence.

context: Her Cynewulf benam Sigebryht his rices \& West Seaxna wiotan| for unryhtum dædum , buton Hamtunscire ;| \& he hæfde þa oþ he #ofslog# þone aldormon þe him lengest| wunode ; \& hiene þa Cynewulf on Andred adræfde ,| \& he þær wunade oþ þæt hiene an swan ofstang æt| Pryfetes flodan ;| \& he wræc þone aldor mon Cumbran ;
trans: This year, Cynewulf, with the consent of the West-Saxon council, deprived his kinsman Sebright of his kingdom for unrighteous deeds, except Hampshire, which he retained until he slew the alderman, who had remained the longest with him. context: Her Ecgbryht cyning #forþferde# , \& hine hæfde ær Offa Miercna| cyning \& Beorhtric Wesseaxna cyning afliemed| iii gear of Angelcynnes lande on Fronclond ær he| cyning wære , \& þy fultumode Beorhtric Offan| þy he hæfde his dohtor him to cuene ; \& se Ecgbryht ricsode| xxxvii wintra \& vii monaþ .
trans: This year died King Egbert. Him Offa, King of Mercia, and Bertric, the West-Saxon king, had driven out of England into France three years before he was king. Bertric assisted Offa because he had married his daughter. And this Egbert reigned thirty-seven winters and seven months.

context: \& þy ilcan geare #cuom# feorðe healfhund scipa on| Temesemuþan , \& bræcon Contwaraburg , \& Lundenburg , \&| gefliemdon Beorhtwulf Miercna cyning mid his fierde , \& foron| þa suþ ofer Temese on Suþrige , \& him| gefeaht wiþ æþelwulf cyning \& æþelbald his sunu æt Aclea| mid West Seaxna fierde , \& þær þæt mæste wæl| geslogon on hæþnum herige þe we secgan hierdon oþ þisne| ondweardan dæg , \& þær sige namon .
trans: The same year, three hundred and fifty ships came into the mouth of the Thames. They stormed Canterbury and London and put Bertulf, king of Mercia, and his army to flight. Then they marched southward over the Thames into Surrey. Here Ethelwulf and his son Ethelbald fought against them at Ockley with the West-Saxon army, and they made the greatest slaughter of the heathen army that we have ever heard reported to this present day, and they obtained the victory.

context: \& on his dæge #cuom# micel sciphere| up \& abræcon Wintanceastre ․| \& wiþ þone here gefuhton Osric aldorman mid Hamtunscire , \&| æþelwulf aldormon mid Bearrucscire , \& þone| here gefliemdon , \& wælstowe gewald ahton ; \& se æþelbryht| ricsode v gear , \& his lic liþ æt Scireburnan .
trans: In his days came a large naval force up into the country, and stormed Winchester. context: \& þær #wæs# micel| ungeþuærnes þære þeode betweox him selfum , \& hie hæfdun| hiera cyning aworpenne Osbryht , \& ungecyndne| cyning underfengon ællan ;
trans: And there was much dissension in that nation among themselves; they had deposed their king Osbert, and had admitted Aella

context: \& hie late on geare to þam #gecirdon# þæt hie wiþ þone| here winnende wærun , \& hie þeah micle fierd gegadrodon ,| \& þone here sohton æt Eoforwicceastre , \& on þa| ceastre bræcon , \& hie sume inne wurdon , \&| þær was ungemetlic wæl geslægen Norþanhymbra , sume| binnan , sume butan ;| \& þa cyningas begen ofslægene , \& sio laf wiþ þone here| friþ nam ;
trans: Spät im Jahr kehrten sie dazu zurück, dass sie mit dem Wikingerheer im Kampf waren, und sie sammelten doch noch ein großes Heer und suchten das Heer auf bei York und stürmten gegen die Stadt an und einige schafften es rein. Then was there an immense slaughter of the Northumbrians, some within and some without; and both the kings were slain on the spot. The survivors made peace with the army.

context: Her #rad# se here ofer Mierce innan East Engle \& wintersetl| namon ․ æt þeodforda , \& þy wintre Eadmund| cyning him wiþ feaht , \& þa Deniscan sige namon , \& þone| cyning ofslogon , \& þæt lond all geeodon ;
trans: This year the army rode over Mercia into East-Anglia, and there fixed their winter-quarters at Thetford. And in the winter King Edmund fought with them; but the Danes gained the victory, and slew the king; whereupon they overran all that land, and destroyed all the monasteries to which they came.

context: Her #cuom# se here to Readingum on West Seaxe , \& þæs ymb| iii niht ridon ii eorlas up ;| þa gemette hie æþelwulf aldorman on Englafelda , \& him þær| wiþ gefeaht \& sige nam ;| þæs ymb iiii niht æþered cyning \& ælfred his broþur| þær micle fierd to Readingum gelæddon , \& wiþ| þone here gefuhton , \& þær wæs micel wæl geslægen on| gehwæþre hond , \& æþelwulf aldormon wearþ ofslægen ,| \& þa Deniscan ahton wælstowe gewald ;
trans: This year came the army to Reading in Wessex; and in the course of three nights after rode two earls up, who were met by Alderman Ethelwulf at Englefield; where he fought with them, and obtained the victory. About four nights after this, King Ethered and Alfred his brother led their main army to Reading, where they fought with the enemy; and there was much slaughter on either hand, Alderman Ethelwulf being among the slain; but the Danes kept possession of the field.

context: \& þæs ymb iiii niht #gefeaht# æþered cyning \& ælfred| his broþur wiþ alne þone here on æscesdune , \&| hie wærun on twæm gefylcum , on oþrum wæs Bachsecg \&| Halfdene þa hæþnan cyningas , \& on oþrum wæron þa eorlas ;| \& þa gefeaht se cyning æþered wiþ þara cyninga getruman ,| \& þær wearþ se cyning Bagsecg ofslægen ;| \& ælfred his broþur wiþ þara eorla getruman , \& þær| wearþ Sidroc eorl ofslægen se alda , \& Sidroc eorl| se gioncga , \& Osbearn eorl , \& Fræna eorl , \& Hareld eorl , \&| þa hergas begen gefliemde , \& fela þusenda| ofslægenra , \& onfeohtende wæron oþ niht .
trans: And about four nights after this, King Ethered and Alfred his brother fought with all the army on Ashdown, and the Danes were overcome. And they were in two divisions; in one of which were Bagsac and Healfden, the heathen kings, and in the other were the earls. King Ethered therefore fought with the troops of the kings, and there was King Bagsac slain; and Alfred his brother fought with the troops of the earls and there were slain Earl Sidrac the elder, Earl Sidrac the younger, Earl Osbern, Earl Frene, and Earl Harold.

context: Her hiene bestæl se here on midne winter ofer tuelftan| niht to Cippanhamme , \& #geridon# Wesseaxna lond| \& gesæton micel þæs folces \& ofer sæ adræfdon , \& þæs| oþres þone mæstan dæl hie geridon , \& him to| gecirdon buton þam cyninge ælfrede ․ \& he lytle werede| unieþelice æfter wudum for , \& on morfæstenum ;
trans: This year about mid-winter, after twelfth nights, the Danish army stole itself away to Chippenham and rode over the land of the West-Saxons, where they settled and drove many of the people over sea. And they rode down the greatest part of the rest and subdued them to their will, except Alfred the king. He and a little troop uneasily sought the woods and the strongholds of the moors.

context: þa on þære seofoðan wiecan ofer Eastron he #gerad# to| Ecgbryhtes stane be eastan Sealwyda , \& him to| com mon þær ongen Sumorsæte alle , \& Wilsætan , \& Hamtunscir| se dæl , se hiere behinon sæ was , \& his gefægene wærun ;

trans: Then within one night he went from this retreat to Hey; and within one night after he proceeded to Heddington; and there fought with all the army, and put them to flight, riding after them as far as the fortress, where he remained a fortnight.

context: \& þa #salde# se here him foregislas \& micle aþas , þæt hie of| his rice uuoldon , \& him eac geheton þæt| hiera kyning fulwihte onfon wolde , \& hie þæt gelæston swa ;| \& þæs ymb iii wiecan com se cyning to him Godrum| þritiga sum þara monna þe in þam here weorþuste| wæron æt Alre , \& þæt is wiþ æþelingga eige ;| \& his se cyning þær onfeng æt fulwihte , \& his crismlising| was æt Weþmor , \& he was xii niht mid þam| cyninge , \& he hine miclum \& his geferan mid feo weorðude .
trans: Then the army gave him hostages with many oaths, that they would go out of his kingdom. They told him also, that their king would receive baptism. And they acted accordingly; for in the course of three weeks after, King Guthrum, attended by some thirty of the worthiest men that were in the army, came to him at Aller, which is near Athelney and there the king became his sponsor in baptism; and his crisom-leasing was at Wedmor. He was there twelve nights with the king, who honoured him and his attendants with many presents.

And they acted accordingly; for in the course of three weeks after, King Guthrum, attended by some thirty of the worthiest men that were in the army, came to him at Aller, which is near Athelney and there the king became his sponsor in baptism; and his crisom-leasing was at Wedmor. He was there twelve nights with the king, who honoured him and his attendants with many presents.

context: \& þrie Scottas #comon# to ælfrede cyninge , on anum bate butan| ælcum gereþrum of Hibernia , þonon hi hi| bestælon forþon þe hi woldon for Godes lufan on| elþiodignesse beon , hi ne rohton hwær ․| Se bat wæs geworht of þriddan healfre hyde þe hi on foron ,| \& hi namon mid him þæt hi hæfdun to seofon| nihtum mete ; \& þa comon hie ymb vii niht to londe on| Cornwalum ․ \& foron þa sona to ælfrede cyninge ;| þus hie wæron genemnde , Dubslane \& Maccbethu ․ \& Maelinmun ․
trans: And three Scots came to King Alfred in a boat without any oars from Ireland; whence they stole away, because they would live in a state of pilgrimage, for the love of God, they recked not where. The boat in which they came was made of two hides and a half; and they took with them provisions for seven nights; and within seven nights they came to land in Cornwall, and soon after went to King Alfred. They were thus named: Dubslane, and Macbeth, and Maelinmun.

context: hæfde Hæsten ær #geworht# þæt geweorc æt Beamfleote , \&| wæs þa utafaren on hergaþ , \& wæs se micla here| æt ham ;| þa foron hie to \& gefliemdon þone here , \& þæt geweorc| abræcon , \& genamon eal þæt þær binnan wæs , ge| on feo ․ ge on wifum , ge eac on bearnum , \& brohton eall in to| Lundenbyrig ,

context: \& þa scipu eall oðþe tobræcon ,| oþþe forbærndon , oþþe to Lundenbyrig #brohton#| oþþe to Hrofesceastre ․| \& Hæstenes wif \& his suna twegen mon brohte to þæm cyninge ,| \& he hi him eft ageaf , forþæm þe hiora| wæs oþer his godsunu , oþer æðeredes ealdormonnes ;

context: hæfdon hi hiora onfangen ær Hæsten to Beamfleote #come# , \& he| him hæfde geseald gislas \& aðas , \& se cyng| him eac wel feoh sealde , \& eac swa þa he þone cniht agef| \& þæt wif ․| ac sona| wæs ․ swa hergode he on his rice þone ilcan ende þe| æþered his cumpæder healdan sceolde ,
trans: They (Alfred and Ethered) had adopted his sons before Hasten came to Bamfleet, and he had given them hostages and oaths. But it was not long, and he was again plundering in the same quarter of his kingdom that Ethered his godfather had to defend.

context: þy ilcan geare #drehton# þa hergas on East Englum \& on| Norðhymbrum West Seaxna lond swiðe be þæm suðstæðe| mid stælhergum , ealra swiþust mid ðæm æscum þe| hie fela geara ær timbredon ․| þa het ælfred cyng timbran lang scipu ongen ða æscas ; þa| wæron fulneah tu swa lange swa þa oðru .

context: þa #com# þæm| Deniscum scipum þeh ær flod to , ær þa Cristnan mehten| hira utascufan , \& hie forðy ut oðreowon ;| þa wæron hie to þæm gesargode ․ þæt hie ne mehton Suð| Seaxna lond utan berowan , ac hira þær tu sæ on| lond wearp ․| \& þa men mon lædde to Winteceastre to þæm cynge , \& he hie| ðær ahon het .

trans: This year Ethelwald enticed the army in East-Anglia to rebellion, so that they overran the land of Mercia, plundering until they came to Cricklade where they crossed the Thames; and they seized, either in Bradon or in the surroundings, all that they could lay their hands upon, and then they turned home again.

context: þa ætsæton ða Centiscan þær beæftan ofer his bebod , \&| seofon ærendracan he him hæfde to asend ․| þa #befor# se here hie ðær , \& hie ðær gefuhton , \& þær| wearð Sigulf ealdormon ofslægen , \& Sigelm ealdormon ,| \& Eadwold cynges ðegen , \& Cenulf abbod , \& Sigebreht| Sigulfes sunu , \& Eadwald Accan sunu , \& monige| eac him , þeh ic ða geðungnestan nemde .
trans: But the Kentish men remained behind, contrary to his order, though he had sent seven messengers to them. Whereupon the army surrounded them, and there they fought. There fell Aldermen Siwulf and Sigelm; Eadwold, the king's thane; Abbot Kenwulf; Sigebriht, the son of Siwulf; Eadwald, the son of Acca; and many also with them; though I have named the most considerable.

context: þa #geascade# se cyng þæt þæt hie ut on hergað foron , þa| sende he his fird ægðer ge of West Seaxum ge| of Mercum , \& hie offoron ðone here hindan , þa he hamweard| wæs , \& him þa wiþ gefuhton , \& þone here| gefliemdon , \& his fela þusenda ofslogon , \& þær wæs Ecwils| cyng ofslægen .

context: Her on þys gere #rad# se here ut ofer Eastron of Hamtune , \& of| Ligeraceastre ․ \& bræcon þone friþ ․ \&| slogon monige men æt Hocneratune , \& þær onbutan ;

context: \& þa swiðe raþe æfter þæm , swa þa oþre ham #comon# , þa| fundon hie oþre flocrade , þæt rad ut wið Lygtunes ,| \& þa wurdon þa landleode his ware , \& him wiþ gefuhton ,| \& gebrohton hie on fullum fleame , \& ahreddon| eall þæt hie genumen hæfdon , \& eac hira horsa \& hira| wæpna micelne dæl :
trans: Then, very soon after this, as the others came home, they found other troops that were riding out against Leighton. And when the inhabitants became aware of it, they fought against them and put them to full flight, and they recovered all that had been taken, including their horses and a great deal of their weapons.

context: Her on þysum geare #com# micel sciphere hider ofer suþan of| Lidwiccum , \& twegen eorlas mid , Ohtor \& Hroald ,| \& foron west onbutan þæt hie gedydon innan Sæferne| muþan , \& hergodon on Norþ Wealas æghwær be| þam sæ , þær hie þonne on hagode ;| \& gefengon Cameleac biscop on Ircinga felda , \& læddon hine| mid him to scipum , \& þa aliesde Eadweard| cyning hine eft mid xl pundum .
trans: This year came a great naval armament over hither south from the Lidwiccians; and two earls with it, Ohter and Rhoald. They went then west about, till they entered the mouth of the Severn; and plundered in North-Wales everywhere by the sea, where it then suited them; and took Camlac the bishop in Archenfield, and led him with them to their ships; whom King Edward afterwards released for forty pounds.

context: þa æfter þam #for# se here eall up , \& wolde faran þa giet on| hergaþ wið Ircingafeldes ; þa gemetton þa| men hie of Hereforda \& of Gleaweceastre ․ \& of þam niehstum| burgum , \& him wið gefuhton , \& hie gefliemdon ;| \& ofslogon þone eorl Hroald \& þæs oþres eorles broþor| Ohteres , \& micel þæs heres ․ \& bedrifon hie on| anne pearruc , \& besæton hie þær utan , oþþe hie him| sealdon gislas , þæt hie of Eadweardes cyninges| anwalde afaran woldon ;
trans: After this went the army all up; and would proceed yet on plunder against Archenfield; but the men of Hertford met them, and of Glocester, and of the nighest towns; and fought with them, and put them to flight; and they slew the Earl Rhoald, and the brother of Ohter the other earl, and many of the army. And they drove them into a park; and beset them there without, until they gave them hostages, that they would depart from the realm of King Edward.

context: \& se cyng #hæfde# funden þæt him mon sæt wiþ on suþhealfe| Sæfernmuþan , westan from Wealum , east oþ Afenemuþan ,| þæt hie ne dorston þæt land nawer gesecan on| þa healfe ;

context: \& þa æfter þam on þam ilcan gere #foran# to Martines| mæssan , ða for Eadweard cyning to Buccingahamme| mid his firde , \& sæt þær feower wucan , \& geworhte þa burga| buta on ægþere healfe eas ær he þonon fore ;| \& þurcytel eorl hine gesohte him to hlaforde , \& þa holdas| ealle , \& þa ieldstan men ealle mæste ðe to| Bedanforda hierdon , \& eac monige þara þe to Hamtune| hierdon .
trans: After this, in the same year, before Martinmas, went King Edward to Buckingham with his army, and sat there four weeks and built the two forts on either side of the water, ere he departed thence. And Earl Thurkytel sought him for his lord; and all the captains, and almost all the first men that belonged to Bedford; and also many of those that belonged to Northampton.

context: Her on þys gere Eadweard cyng #for# mid fierde to Bedanforda| foran to Martines mæssan , \& beget þa burg ,| \& him cirdon to mæst ealle þa burgware þe hie ær budon ,| \& he sæt þær feower wucan , \& het atimbran| þa burg on suþ healfe þære eas ær he þonan fore :
trans: This year King Edward went with his army to Bedford, before Martinmas, and conquered the town; and almost all the inhabitants, who they commanded before, returned to him; and he sat there four weeks, and ordered the town to be repaired on the south side of the water, ere he departed thence.

context: þy ilcan sumera betwix hlafmæssan \& middum sumera se here| #bræc# þone friþ of Hamtune , \& of Ligeraceastre ,| \& þonan norþan , \& foron to Tofeceastre , \& fuhton on| þa burg ealne dæg , \& þohton þæt hie hie sceolden| abrecen ;| ac hie þeah awerede þæt folc þe þær binnan wæs oþ him| mara fultum tocom , \& hie forleton þa þa burg ,| \& foron aweg ;
trans: The same summer, between Lammas and midsummer, the army broke their parole from Northampton and from Leicester, and went thence northward to Towcester, and fought against the town all day. They thought that they should break into it, but the people within defended it until more aid arrived. And then they abandoned the town and went away.

context: \& þa eft swiðe raþe æfter þam hie #foron# eft ut mid| stælherge nihtes , \& comon on ungearwe men , \& genomon| unlytel , ægþer ge on mannum , ge on ierfe .

context: þy ilcan siþe #for# se here of Huntandune , \& of East Englum , \&| worhton þæt geweorc æt Tæmeseforda , \&| hit budon \& bytledon , \& forleton þæt oþer æt Huntandune , \&| þohton þæt hie sceoldon þanon of mid gewinne| \& mid unfriðe eft þæs landes mare geræcan ;
trans: At the same time went the army from Huntington and East-Anglia, and constructed that work at Ternsford; which they inhabited and fortified; and abandoned the other at Huntingdon; and thought that they should thence oft with war and contention recover a good deal of this land.

context: þa eft æfter þam þa giet #gegadorode# micel here hine of| East Englum \& of Mercnalande , \& foran to þære| byrig æt Wigingamere , \& ymbsæton hie utan , \& fuhton lange| on dæg on , \& namon þone ceap onbutan ; \&| þa men aweredon| þeah þa burg þe þær binnan wæron , \&| þa forleton hie þa burg \& foron aweg .
trans: Then again, after this, a great army yet collected itself from East-Anglia and from Mercia and went to the town of Wigmore; which they besieged without, and fought against long in the day; and took the cattle about it; but the men defended the town, who were within; and the enemy left the town, and went away.

context: þa æfter þam þæs ilcan sumeres #gegadorode# micel folc hit| on Eadweardes cynges anwalde ․ of þam niehstum| burgum , þe hit ða gefaran mehte , \& foron to| Tæmeseforda ․ \& besæton ða burg ․ \& fuhton ðær on oð| hi hie abræcon , \& ofslogon þone cyning , \& Toglos eorl , \&| Mannan eorl his sunu , \& his broþor , \& ealle| þa þe þær binnan wæron , \& hie wergan woldon , \& namon| þa oþre \& eal þæt þær binnan wæs .
trans: After this, the same summer, a large force collected itself in King Edward's dominions, from the nighest towns that it could get hold of, and went to Temsford; and they beset the town, and fought thereon; until they broke into it and slew the king, and Earl Toglos, and Earl Mann his son, and his brother, and all them that were therein, and who were resolved to defend it; and they took the others, and all that was therein.

context: þa æfter þam þæs forhraþe #gegadorode# micel folc hit on| hærfest , ægþer ge of Cent , ge of Suþrigum , ge| of East Seaxum , ge æghwonan of þam nihstum burgum , \& foron| to Colneceastre , \& ymbsæton þa burg , \&| þær on fuhton oþ hie þa geeodon , \& þæt folc eall| ofslogon , \& genamon eal þæt þær binnan wæs , buton| þam mannum þe þær oþflugon ofer þone weall .

context: þa æfter þam þa giet þæs ilcan hærfestes #gegadorode#| micel here hine of East Englum ․ ægþer ge þæs landheres| ge þara wicinga þe hie him to fultume aspanen| hæfdon , \& þohton þæt hie sceoldon gewrecan hira| teonun , \& foron to Mældune , \& ymbsæton þa burg , \& fuhton| þær on , oþ þam burgwarum com mara fultum| to utan to helpe , \& forlet se here þa burg , \& for fram ;| \& þa foron þa men æfter ut of þære byrig , \& eac þa þe| him utan comon to fultume , \& gefliemdon þone| here \& ofslogon hira monig hund , ægþer ge æsc manna ge| oþerra .
trans: After this again, this same harvest, a great army collected itself from East-Anglia, both of the landforces and of the pirates, which they had enticed to their assistance, and thought that they should wreak their vengeance. They went to Maldon, and beset the town, and fought thereon, until more aid came to the townsmen from without to help. The enemy then abandoned the town, and went from it. And the men went after, out of the town, and also those that came from without to their aid; and put the army to flight, and slew many hundreds of them, both of the pirates and of the others.

context: þa þæs forhraþe þæs ilcan hærfestes #for# Eadweard cyning| mid West Sexna fierde to Passanhamme , \& sæt| þær þa hwile þe mon worhte þa burg æt Tofeceastre mid| stanwealle , \& him cirde to þurferþ eorl , \& þa| holdas , \& eal se here þe to Hamtune hierde norþ oþ| Weolud , \& sohton hine him to hlaforde \& to mundboran ;
trans: Soon after this, the same harvest, went King Edward with the West-Saxon army to Passham; and sat there the while that men fortified the town of Towcester with a stone wall. And there returned to him Earl Thurferth, and the captains, and all the army that belonged to Northampton northward to the Welland, and sought him for their lord and protector.

context: \& þa se firdstemn #for# ham , þa for oþer ut , \& gefor þa burg| æt Huntandune , \& hie gebette \& geedneowade| þær heo ær tobrocen wæs , be Eadweardes cyninges hæse ,| \& þæt folc eal þæt þær to lafe wæs þara landleoda| beag to Eadwearde cyninge , \& sohton his friþ \& his| mundbyrde .
trans: When this division of the army went home, then went another out, and marched to the town of Huntingdon; and repaired and renewed it, where it was broken down before, by command of King Edward. And all the people of the country that were left submitted to King Edward, and sought his peace and protection.

context: Her on ðissum geare #com# Unlaf mid þrim \& hund ․| nigentigon scipum to Stane , \& forhergedon þæt on ytan , \& for| ða ðanon to Sandwic, \& swa ðanon to Gipeswic,| \& þæt eall ofereode , \& swa to Mældune;| \& him þær com togeanes Byrhtnoð ealdorman mid his fyrde , \&| him wið gefeaht ․ \& hy þone ealdorman þær| ofslogon , \& wælstowe geweald ahtan ․ \& him man nam syððan| frið wið , \& hine nam se cing syððan to bisceopes| handa ․ ðurh Sirices lare Cantware biscpes , \&| ælfeages Wincæstre biscop .
trans: This year came Anlaf with three and ninety ships to Staines, which he plundered without, and went thence to Sandwich. Thence to Ipswich, which he laid waste; and so to Maidon, where Alderman Britnoth came against him with his force, and fought with him; and there they slew the alderman, and gained the field of battle; whereupon peace was made with him, and the king received him afterwards at episcopal hands by the advice of Siric, Bishop of Canterbury, and Elfeah of Winchester.

context: Her on þysum geare #wæs# micel unfrið on Angelcynnes londe| þurh sciphere, \& welgehwær hergedon \& bærndon ,| swa þæt hy upp asetton on ænne siþ þæt hy coman| to æþelingadene ․| \& þa com þær togeanes Hamtunscir , \& him wið gefuhton ․ \&| ðær wearð æþelweard cinges heah gerefa ofslegen ․| \& Leofric æt Hwitciricean , \& Leofwine cinges| heahgerefa , \& Wulfhere bisceopes ðegn , \& Godwine| æt Worðige, ælfsiges bisceopes sunu ․ \& ealra manna an \&| hundeahtatig ․| \& þær wearð þara Denescra micle ma ofslegenra ․ þeah ðe| hie wælstowe geweald ahtan .
trans: This year there was great commotion in England in consequence of an invasion by the Danes who spread terror and devastation wheresoever they went, plundering and burning and desolating the country with such rapidity, that they advanced in one march as far as the town of Alton; where the people of Hampshire came against them, and fought with them. There was slain Ethelwerd, high-steward of the king, and Leofric of Whitchurch, and Leofwin, high-steward of the king, and Wulfhere, a bishop's thane, and Godwin of Worthy, son of Bishop Elfsy; and of all the men who were engaged with them eighty-one. Of the Danes there was slain a much greater number, though they remained in possession of the field of battle.

context: \& #foran# ða þanon west oþ þæt hy coman to Defenan, \& him| þær togeanes com Pallig mid þan scipan ðe he| gegaderian mihte, forþam þe he asceacen wæs fram| æðelrede cyncge ofer ealle ða getrywða ðe he him| geseald hæfde , \& eac se cyng him wel gegifod hæfde on| hamon , \& on golde \& seolfre ․| \& forbærndon Tegntun , \& eac fela oðra godra hama þe we| genemnan ne cunnan , \& heom man syððan þær frið wið nam .
trans: Thence they proceeded westward, until they came into Devonshire; where Paley came to meet them with the ships which he was able to collect; for he had shaken off his allegiance to King Ethelred, against all the vows of truth and fidelity which he had given him, as well as the presents which the king had bestowed on him in houses and gold and silver. And they burned Teignton, and also many other goodly towns that we cannot name; and then peace was there concluded with them.

context: \& hy #foran# þa þanon to Exanmuðan, swa þæt hy asettan him| upp on ænne sið oð hy coman to Peonho , \& þær| wæs Kola ðæs cyninges heahgerefa , \& Eadsige þæs| cynincges gerefa togeanes him mid ðære fyrde ðe| hy gegaderian mihtan , \& hy ðær aflymede wurdon , \& ðær| wearð fela ofslegenra , \& ða Denescean ahtan wælstowe| geweald ;
trans: And they proceeded thence towards Exmouth, so that they marched at once till they came to Pin-hoo; where Cole, high-steward of the king, and Edsy, reve of the king, came against them with the army that they could collect. But they were there put to flight and there were many slain, and the Danes had possession of the field of battle.

context: \& ðæs on mergen forbærndon þone ham æt Peonho , \& æt| Glistune , \& eac fela godra hama þe we #genemnan#| na cunnan, \& foran ða eft east ongean oð hy coman to Wiht ;| \& þæs on mergen forbærndon ðone ham æt Wealtham ․ \& oðra| cotlifa fela ․ \& heom man raþe þæs wiðþingode ․| \& hy namon frið.
trans: And the next morning they burned the village of Pin-hoo, and of Clist, and also many goodly towns that we cannot name. Then they returned eastward again, till they came to the Isle of Wight. The next morning they burned the town of Waltham, and many other small towns; soon after which the people treated with them, and they made peace.

context: Soð ic eow #secge# , þæt| ge sylfe ne becumað into heofonan rice , butan eower rihtwisnys| beo eallunga mare ætforan minum Fæder þonne þæra bocera| is and ðæra Sunderhalgena .
trans: Wahrlich, ich sage euch, dass ihr selbst nicht ins Himmelreich kommen werdet, wenn eure Rechtschaffenheit gegenüber meinem Vater nicht gänzlich größer ist als die der Gelehrten und der Pharisäer. (Mt 5,20)

context: Ge #gehyrdon# þa bebodu þe God bebead gefyrn þam ealdan| Israhele under Moyses lage , and hym þus sæde :| Ne ofsleh þu mannan ;| and se ðe man ofslihð , se bið domes scyldig .
trans: Ihr habt die Gebote gehört, die Gott uns vor langer Zeit dem alten Israel unter Moses Gesetz beboten hat, und er sagte ihnen: Du sollst keinen Menschen töten, und wer einen Menschen tötet, der soll durch das Gericht verurteilt werden. (Mt 5,21)

context: Ic #secge# eow to soðan þæt se bið domes scyldig , se ðe nu| yrsað wið his agenne broðor ․| Se ðe him hosp gecwyð , se bið þeahtes scyldig , and se ðe| hine hæt stuntne , se bið wites scyldig on þam| witnigendlican fyre þære toweardan worulde , buton he| ðone gylt gebete on his life .
trans: Ich sage euch wahrlich, dass der vor Gericht verurteilt werden soll, der gegen seinen eigenen Bruder erzürnt. Wer ihn beleidigt, der soll vor dem Rat verurteilt werden, und wer ihn dumm nennt, der soll zu einer Strafe verurteilt werden im strafenden Feuer der zukünftigen Welt, wenn er seine Schuld nicht zu seinen Lebzeiten begleicht. (Mt 5,22)

context: Gif ðu #geoffrast# Gode ænige lac æt his weofode , and þu| þonne geþencst þæt þin broðor hæfð sum þing| ongean þe , gesete þine lac ætforan þam weofode , and fær| ðe ærest hraðe to þinum agnum breðer , and hine geglada ;| and þonne þu eft cymst , geoffra þine lac .
trans: Wenn du Gott irgendeine Gabe opferst an seinem Altar und dir dann einfällt, dass dein Bruder eine Sache gegen dich hat, setze deine Gabe vor den Altar und gehe schnell zu deinem Bruder und besänftige ihn; und wenn du dann zurückkommst, opfere deine Gabe. (Mt 5,23f.)

context: and we #secgað#| eow þæt sume men wendon þæt seo ealde æ on Moyses timan| wære miccle stiðre mannum to gehealdenne þonne Cristes| boboda , þe he gecwæð him sylf on ðære niwan lage æfter| his tocyme , under Godes gife , on ðæs godspelles timan ,| swa swa we healdan sceolon gif we hyrað Gode ;
trans: Und wir sagen euch, dass manche Menschen glaubten, das alte Gesetz zu Moses Zeiten sei den Menschen sehr viel härter zu befolgen gewesen als Christus’ Gebote, die er ihnen im neuen Testament nach seiner Ankunft selbst gesagt hat, in Gottes Gnaden zu den Zeiten des Evangeliums, so wie wir es befolgen sollen, wenn wir auf Gott hören.

and we| sceolon liðian and ure lif awendan to ðæs Hælendes bebodum ,| gif we habban #wyllað# þa micclan myrhðe mid him , swa swa he| us behet .
We ne #magon# libban on ðisum life nateshwon , þæt we ne| agylton wið God and wið men on worde and on weorce ; ac we| sceolon symble| to Gode gecyrran and his mildsunge biddan ;
trans: Wir dürfen keineswegs so in diesem Leben leben, dass wir nicht gegen Gott und die Menschen sündigen mit Wort und Tat, sondern wir sollen uns stets zu Gott hinwenden und um seine Gnade bitten.

context: for ðon þe he is| gearu , gif we hine #biddað# mid inneweardre heortan , þæt he| us mildsige ; and him is miccle leofre ures lifes rihting| þonne ænig oðer sceat , gif we geswicað yfeles .
trans: Denn er ist bereit, wenn wir ihn aus tiefstem Herzen bitten, dass er sich unser erbarme; und ihm ist die Berichtigung unseres Lebensweges viel lieber als irgendein anderer Schatz, wenn wir vom Bösen ablassen.

context: for ðon þe he is| gearu , gif we hine biddað mid inneweardre heortan , þæt he| us mildsige ; and him is miccle leofre ures lifes rihting| þonne ænig oðer sceat , gif we #geswicað# yfeles .

context: ælce dæg we #syngiað# , and ælce dæg we sceolon urne Hælend| gladian mid sumre godnysse , se ðe æfre wile us mannum| mildsian ; and he nyle naht eaðe þæs synfullan deað , ac he| swyðor wyle þæt he gecyrre and lybbe ; and se ðe bote| underfehð , and he beo syððan hræðe þæs of life , he| sceal to reste gewiss , for þon þe he gecyrde fram his| synnum to Gode .
trans: Jeden Tag singen wir, und jeden Tag müssen wir unseren Heiland ehren mit mancher Güte, der sich stets uns Menschen erbarmen wird, und er will nicht einfach den Tod des Sündigen, sondern er will vielmehr, dass er sich bekehre und lebe; ebenso der, der Hilfe bekommt – auch wenn er kurz darauf verstirbt, denn er hat sich von seinen Sünden zu Gott gewandt.

context: Se Hælend us #sæde# , swa swa ge gehyrdon ær , Soð ic eow| secge , þæt ge sylfe ne becumað into heofonan| rice , buton eower rihtwisnys beo eallunga mare ætforan minum| Fæder þonne þæra bocera is and ðæra Sunderhalgena .
trans: Der Heiland sagte uns, wie ihr vorhin gehört habt: ‘Wahrlich, ich sage euch, dass ihr selbst nicht ins Himmelreich kommen werdet, wenn eure Rechtschaffenheit nicht ganz und gar mehr gegenüber meinem Vater ist, als es die der Gelehrten und der Pharisäer ist.’

context: þa boceras syndon and þa Sundorhalgan þa ealdan witan , þe| #wæron# gefyrn , under Moyses lage , swa micclum gelærede þæt| hy ða ealdan æ on heora wisan cuðon ; ac hy ne heoldon| swaþeah þa halgan Godes æ swa wel swa hy sceoldon .
trans: Die Gelehrten sind es und die Pharisäer, die alten Weisen, die damals, unter Moses Gesetz, so sehr gelehrt waren, dass sie das alte Gesetz in ihrer Sprache kannten; aber trotzdem befolgten sie das heilige Gesetz Gottes nicht so gut, wie sie sollten.

Uos iustificatis| uos coram hominibus ; Deus , autem , nouit corda uestra : Ge| #tellað# eow rihtwise on manna gesihþum , ac God soðlice cann| swaðeah eowere heortan ; ge synd swa swa byrgenu þe beoð| wiðutan agrafene mid ofergeweorcum , swiðe wel amette ,| and syndon afyllede mid forrotodnysse ; and ge swaþeah lufiað| hlisan and herunge .

Uos iustificatis| uos coram hominibus ; Deus , autem , nouit corda uestra : Ge| tellað eow rihtwise on manna gesihþum , ac God soðlice #cann#| swaðeah eowere heortan ; ge synd swa swa byrgenu þe beoð| wiðutan agrafene mid ofergeweorcum , swiðe wel amette ,| and syndon afyllede mid forrotodnysse ; and ge swaþeah lufiað| hlisan and herunge .
Hym wæs beboden , on heora gehealdsumnyssum on Moyses lage ,| þæt hy #moston# lufian heora agene frynd ,| and hatian heora fynd ;

ac us #bead# se Hælend , her on ðysum| life , þæt we lufian sceolon symble , butan hiwunge , ure| agene freond , and ælcne Cristene man , and eac for Godes| lufan lufian ure fynd , þæt ure rihtwisnys beo mare þonne| heora , we ðe habban sceolon þæt heofonlice lif , gif we| gehyrsume beoð Godes hæsum mid weorcum .
trans: Aber uns gebot der Heiland, hier in diesem Leben, dass wir stets lieben sollen, ohne Scheinheiligkeit, unseren eigenen Freund und jeden christlichen Menschen, und auch um Gottes Liebe willen unsere Feinde lieben, damit unsere Rechtschaffenheit größer sei als ihre; wir, die das Leben im Himmel haben werden, wenn wir Gottes Geboten mit unseren Taten gehorsam sind.

context: Hym wæs beboden þæt hy ne hæmdon unrihtlice| wið oþra manna wif ; ac us #sæde# Crist þus : Omnis qui| uiderit mulierem ad concupiscendum eam iam mechatus est eam| in corde suo ;
þæt is on Englisc , ælc man| þe #sceawað# wifman mid luste , þæt he hy habban wolde ,| þæt him witodlice bið þæt forliger gefremod on his| agenre heortan þurh þone unlust , þæt he hire gewilnode .
trans: Das heißt auf Englisch: Jeder Mann, der eine Frau mit Lust anschaut, \idest sie haben will, begeht in seinem Herzen zweifellos Ehebruch durch sein böses Verlangen, weil er sie begehrt hat.

context: Hy #tæhton# mid wordum , swa swa hit awriten is , Godes lare| mannum , and forleton þa weorc ; ac se biþ mære lareow ,| swa swa se Hælend sæde , se þe him sylf gedeð , and he| syððan swa tæcð , and onginneð þa bysne on him sylfum| ærest .
trans: Sie lehrten mit Worten, so wie es geschrieben steht, die Lehre Gottes den Menschen und ließen ihre Arbeit zurück; Aber es ist der ein großartiger Lehrer, wie der Heiland sagte, der selbst tut und anschließend so lehrt, und bei sich selbst die Beispiele beginnt.

context: and Crist witodlice behet þæt ece lif þam þe his word| #healdað# , þæt þe mannes eage ne mihte geseon , ne eare| gehyran , ne heorte asmeagan , þa micclan mærðe þe se| mildheorta Crist þam eallum behet þe hine lufiað ;
trans: Und Christus versprach wahrlich das ewige Leben jenen, die sein Wort achten, das das Auge eines Menschen nicht sehen kann, das Ohr nicht hören, das Herz nicht begreifen; und großen Ruhm, den der barmherzige Christus allen versprach, die ihn lieben.

context: Nu #mote# we habban maran rihtwisnysse , nu us synd behatene þa| heofonlican speda , þæt we moton sona| siþian to Criste on urum forðsiþe , gif we ær mid wærscipe| ure synna gebetað sylfwilles on life .

context: Ge #gehyrdon# þa bebodu þe God bebead gefyrn þam ealdan| Israhele under Moyses lage , and hym þus sæde :| Ne ofslih ðu mannan ; and se ðe man ofslihð , se bið| domes scyldig .
trans: Ihr habt die Gebote gehört, die Gott einst dem alten Israel unter Moses’ Gesetz auferlegt hat, und ihnen folgendermaßen gesagt hat: Du sollst keinen Menschen töten, und wer einen Menschen tötet, der soll vor Gericht verurteilt werden.

context: Ic #secge# eow to soþan þæt se bið domes scyldig , se ðe nu| yrsað wið his agenne broðor ․| On ðam dome man toscæt hwilc his scyld wære , and oft he| bið unscyldig on ðam dome getæht , se ðe ær| wæs geteald þæt he scyldig wære ; and man mæg gegladian| mid godum willan| þa færlican yrsunge , and forfon mid wisdome ,| eað þonne he gebete gif he bið ofslagen .
trans: Ich sage euch wahrlich, dass der vor Gericht verurteilt werden soll, der gegen seinen eigenen Bruder erzürnt. Vor Gericht entscheidet man, worin seine Schuld besteht, und oft wird jemand von Schuld freigesprochen, dem vorher gesagt wurde, dass er schuldig sei. Und die plötzlichen Zornesausbrüche kann man einfacher mit gutem Willen besänftigen und mit Weisheit unter Kontrolle bringen, wenn er seine Schulden begleicht, als wenn er erschlagen wird.

Und die plötzlichen Zornesausbrüche kann man einfacher mit gutem Willen besänftigen und mit Weisheit unter Kontrolle bringen, wenn er seine Schulden begleicht, als wenn er erschlagen wird.

context: To ægþer þæra þinga , þæt is yrre and mansliht , #gæð# se| rihta dom ;

context: ac hit #bið# swaþeah leohtre on bote on ðam| lybbendan men , þeah þe he yrsige , and hit eft gehæle , swa| swa þis godspell on æfteweardan sægð , þæt we magon| gegladian þone þe we ær abulgon .
trans: Aber es ist trotzdem leichter zu sühnen an dem lebenden Menschen, auch wenn er zürnt und es danach wieder heilt, so wie dieses Evangelium später sagt, dass wir den, den wir vorher verärgert haben, wieder zufrieden stellen können.

context: Se þe his breþer hosp #gecwyð# , se bið þeahtes scyldig .
trans: Wer seinen Bruder beleidigt, der soll durch den Rat verurteilt werden (reus erit concilio).

context: Her syndon nu twa þing , þæt yrre and se hosp , and þær| #gæð# geþeaht to þam twam þingum , þæt man mid geþeahte| secge him his wite , hwæt he sylf þrowige for ðam twam| þingum ; ac swaþeah hwilon swa scyldig man ætwint ,| be ðam þe se trahtnere us sægð on Leden .
trans: Hier sind nun zwei Dinge: der Ärger und die Gotteslästerung, und dort kommt Bedacht zu den zwei Dingen, dass man mit Bedacht ihm seine Strafe sage, was er selbst erleiden soll für die zwei Dinge; aber trotzdem flieht so ein schuldiger Mann manchmal; wozu uns der Kommentator auf Latein etwas sagt.

context: Her syndon nu þreo þing , and forþig mare wite : þæt yrre| and se hosp , and eac teonræden ; and þas þing #sceolon# ,| swa swa us sægð seo boc , on ðam toweardan wite| beon afeormode , buton se man hy sylfwilles gebete .
trans: Hier sind nun drei Dinge, und deswegen auch mehr Strafe: der Ärger, die Gotteslästerung und der Misbrauch; diese Dinge sollen, wie uns das Buch sagt, von der drohenden Strafe gereinigt werden, außer der Mann begleiche sie freiwillig.

context: God #cwæð# þurh his witegan þæt he wolde mildsian ælcum| men þe gecyrð fram his synnum to him , þam þe| mid geomerunge gewyrcð dædbote , and his synna ne| beoð syþþan on gemynde .

Paulus se Apostol on his pistole #cwæð# þus : Argue ,| obsecra , increpa , in omni patientia et doctrina :
þrea| ðu and #bide# , cid mid geðylde , on ealre lare to| lifes bebodum .
trans: Kritisiere, harre aus und kämpfe mit Geduld, in aller Lehre zu den Geboten des Lebens.

context: Gif hwa nu þurh steore sum styrne word #gecwyð# to his| underþeoddum for heora stuntnysse , ne bið na þæt gelic| þam unþeawfæstan men , þe for his receleaste| misræceð oðerne , for nanre steore , ac for stuntnesse .
trans: Wenn jemand nun ein ernstes Wort der Züchtigung zu seinen Untergebenen wegen ihrer Dummheit spricht, dann ist das nicht dasselbe wie bei einem lasterhaften Menschen, der wegen seiner Unachtsamkeit einen anderen verleumdet, nicht zur Züchtigung, sondern aus Dummheit.

context: We #sceolon# us gebletsian and abiddan æt Gode þat he us| gehealde , and urne muð þurhhlynne , swa swa| se witega bæd , þysum wordum cweðende : Pone , Domine ,| custodiam ori meo , et hostium circumstantie labiis meis :

context: Gif ðu #geoffrast# Gode ænige lac æt his weofode , and þu| þonne geðencst þæt þin broðor hæfð sum ðing| ongean þe , gesete þine lac ætforan þam weofode , and far| þe ærest raðe to þinum agenum breðer , and hine geglada ;| and þonne þu eft cymst , geoffra þine lac .
trans: Wenn du Gott irgendeine Gabe opferst an seinem Altar und dir dann einfällt, dass dein Bruder eine Sache gegen dich hat, setze deine Gabe vor den Altar und gehe schnell zu deinem Bruder und besänftige ihn; und wenn du dann zurückkommst, opfere deine Gabe. (Mt 5,23f.)

Se Hælend cwæð eft on sumere oðre stowe , þonne ge sylfe| #standað# on eowrum gebedum , forgifað þonne on eowrum heortum| eallum oðrum mannum þe wið eow agyltað þæt se Heofonlica| Fæder eowre synna forgife ; and butan ge forgifon , ne forgifð| he na eow .

þonne hæfð ure broðor sum þing ongean us , gif we him| deredon oððe #gedydon# unðanc ; þonne sceole we don be ures| Drihtnes lare , gegladian urne broðor mid goodum ingehyde ,| þone Cristenan man , butan ælcere hiwunge ,
trans: Wenn unser Bruder eine Sache gegen uns hat, weil wir ihn verletzt oder ihm etwas Schlimmes angetan haben, dann sollen wir gemäß dem Gesetz unseres Herren handeln: unseren Bruder zufrieden stimmen in ehrlicher Absicht, den christlichen Menschen, ohne jegliche Scheinheiligkeit.

context: æfter ðeawlicum andgite se ðe leahtras begæð deofle to| gecwemednysse his #scyppende# on teonan ․ his dohtor is untwylice| awedd ․ for ðan ðe his sawul is ðearle ðurh deofol gedreht ․| ac him is neod þæt he his agene wodnysse tocnawe ․ and mid| geleafan æt godes halgum þingunge bidde ․ and mid micelre| anrædnysse drihtnes fet gesece ․ biddende þæt he his sawle| fram ðam wodan dreame ahredde ․ swa swa he dyde þæt| chananeisce mæden ;
trans: According to the figurative sense, he who commits sins, to the gratification of the devil, and in contumely to his Creator, his daughter is undoubtedly mad, for his soul is sorely tormented by the devil; but it is needful to him that he know his own madness, and with belief pray to God's saints for their intercession, and with great steadfastness seek the feet of the Lord, praying him to save his soul from that state of madness, as he did for the Canaanitish maiden.

Ac hi sona #geswicon# þæs sinscipes æfre , syððan hi Cristes| lare geleornodon æt him , swa swa Petrus sæde on sumum| godspelle :| Ecce nos reliquimus omnia et secuti sumus te ․| Quid ergo erit nobis ?
trans: Und sobald sie Christus’ Lehre von ihm lernten, ließen sie bald von der Ehe ab, so wie Petrus in einem Evangelium sagte: ‘Siehe, wir haben alles zurückgelassen und sind dir gefolgt. Was werden wir bekommen?’ (Mt 19,27)

context: And him #andwyrde# Crist : Ge , þe folgiað me , for þi ge| sceolon sittan on twelf domsetlum , and ge deman sceolon| eallum manncynne on þam micclan dæge æfter þam| æriste , þonne ic sylf sitte on þam domsetle mines| mægenþrymmes .
trans: Und Christus antwortete ihnen: Ihr, die ihr mir folgt, dafür sollte ihr auf zwölf Richterstühlen sitzen, und ihr sollt über die ganze Menschheit richten, an dem großen Tag nach der Auferstehung, wenn ich selbst auf dem Richterstuhl meiner Herrlichkeit sitze.

context: ðysne wurðmynt #geearniað# æt þam ælmihtigan gode þa þe| mid clænnysse him gecwemað on life and mid godum weorcum| hine gladiað nu , þæt hi be hundfealdum habbað þa mede ,| þæt þæt hi be anfealdan for his lufon dydon , and þær| to eacan syþþan þæt ece lif mid him .
trans: Diese Würde verdienen diejenigen vor dem allmächtigen Gott, die ihm mit Reinheit im Leben dienen und ihm nun mit guten Taten gefällig sind, sodass sie hundertfach für das entlohnt werden, was sie aus reiner Liebe zu ihm getan haben, und dazu später das ewige Leben mit ihm erhalten.

Se bisceop þa moste under Moyses æ habban wif and cild for| þære gesetnysse , þe nan mann ne #moste# to| þam micclum hade nateshwon becuman buton of Aarones cynne ,| þæs forman bisceopes , be godes gesetnysse .
Hit #mihte# þa swa wel beon , forþam þe hi ne mæssodon| næfre , ne husel ne halgodon , ærþan þe se hælend| sylf husel gehalgode ær his þrowunge and het us swa don on| his halgan gemynde .
trans: Es kann gut so sein, da sie nie die Messe geleistet haben, kein Abendmahl geheiligt haben, bevor der Heiland selbst das Abendmahl heiligte vor seinem Leiden und uns auftrug, ebenso zu tun in seinem heiligen Andenken.

context: He ne #gecyst# nu be nanum cynrene , ac of ælcere mægðe be| þæs mannes geþingðum , to his halgum þenungum him to| mæssigenne bisceopas and mæssepreostas to swa mycelre gerynu ,| þæt hi halgian magon mid heora þenungum þæt halige husel| to his lichaman and blode , and he wyle habban huru þa clænan| to swylcum weorce , swa swa him wel gerist .
trans: Er wählt nicht nach der Familie, sondern von jedem Stamm gemäß des Mannes Würde zu seinem heiligen Kirchendienst die Bischöfe und Priester zu dem so großen Geheimnis, dass sie das geweihte Opfer heiligen mögen zu seinem Leib und Blut, und er will die Reinen von ihnen zu einem solchen Werk haben, so wie es ihm wohl zukommt.

Iohannes , se godspellere , on his gastlican gesihðe ,| Apocalipsis #gehaten# , þe se hælend him onwreah ,| geseah Crist standan and þone clænan flocc mid him ,| hundteontig þusenda and feower and feowertig þusenda ,| swiðe hlude singende þone heofonlican sang , and nan| oþer halig mann ne mihte singan mid him þone gastlican| lofsang on godes gesihðe , buton þa þusenda , þe þuss| synd geherode .

context: Hi sindon mægðhade #gehealdenre# clænnysse .
trans: Sie sind vom Jungfrauenstand der bewahrten Reinheit.

context: Hi folgiað Criste , swa hwider swa he #gæð# .
trans: Sie folgen Christus, egal wohin er geht.

context: Ac þa godes þeowas , þe gode #sceolon# þenian , gyf hi licgað| nu on heora lustum her , þonne ne magon hi| singan þone heofonlican sang , ne Criste folgian on his| fægerum wununge , þe þa clænnysse lufað on his clænum| þeowdome .
trans: Und die Diener Gottes, die Gott dienen sollen; wenn sie nun hier ihren Gelüsten anhängen, dann können sie den himmlischen Gesang nicht singen und nicht Christus folgen in seine schöne(?) Wohnung, die die Keuschheit lieben in seinem reinen Dienst.

context: Is nu for ði mycel neod læwedum mannum , þæt hi #leornion#| heora geleafan æt Cristes lareowum , and hu| hi lybbon on riht on godes gelaðunge , forþan ðe þry hadas| syndon , þe fullice gode liciað .
trans: Deswegen besteht für die ungelernten Menschen große Not, dass sie von den Lehrern Christi ihren Glauben lernen, und wie sie Leben in Recht nach Gottes Weisung, denn es gibt drei Weihen, die Gott vollumfänglich gefallen.

context: Hit wære swyþe rihtlic æfter rihtum life , þæt se cniht| #heolde# hine sylfne clæne , oð þæt he wifode ,| swa swa he wyle habban clæne mæden , þonne hi cumað| togæderes .

context: And æfter godes gesetnysse eall swa scyldig byð #geteald# se| forlegena cniht swa þæt forlegene mæden .
Wudewanhad is , þæt man #wunige# on clænnysse for godes lufon ,| swa swa þæt godspell segð , æfter his gemacan mid| anrædnysse , ægðer ge weras ge wif æfter godes wissunge .
Wudewanhad is , þæt man wunige on clænnysse for godes lufon ,| swa swa þæt godspell #segð# , æfter his gemacan mid| anrædnysse , ægðer ge weras ge wif æfter godes wissunge .

Hit byð swyþe sceandlic , þæt eald wif #sceole# ceorles| brucan , þonne heo forwerod byð and teames ætealdod ,| ungehealtsumlice , forðan ðe gesceafta ne beoð for| nanum oðran þinge astealde butan for bearnteame anum ,| swa swa us secgað halige bec .

Hit byð swyþe sceandlic , þæt eald wif sceole ceorles| brucan , þonne heo forwerod byð and teames ætealdod ,| ungehealtsumlice , forðan ðe gesceafta ne beoð for| nanum oðran þinge astealde butan for bearnteame anum ,| swa swa us #secgað# halige bec .

Mægðhad is witodlice se þe #wunað# on clænnysse æfre fram| cildhade gesælig for Criste , ge wæpmenn , ge| wimmenn , þa þe wurðiað Crist mid swa micelre lufe , þæt| him leofre byð , þæt hi mid earfoðnysse hi sylfe gewyldon| to þære clænnysse , þe hi Criste beheton , þonne hi heora| lustas on heora life gefremmon| and fram þam ecan wurðmynte ælfremede beon ;
trans: Jungfräulichkeit ist wahrlich, wer stets von Kindheit an heiligmäßig um Christi willen in Reinheit lebt, sowohl Männer als auch Frauen, die Christus mit so großer Liebe verehren, dass es ihnen lieber ist, sich mit Anstrengung zu der Reinheit zu zwingen, die sie Christus versprachen, als dass sie ihre Gelüste in ihrem Leben erfüllen und von der ewigen Würde abgeschnitten sind.

context: Her is seo halige þrinnis on þisum þrim mannum : se| ælmihtiga Fæder of nanum oðrum #gecumen# , \& se| micla Wisdom of þam wisan Fæder æfre of him anum butan| anginne acenned , se þe us alisde of urum þeowte| syððan mid þære menniscnisse , þe he of Marian genam ;

context: Se ælmihtiga Scippend , ða ða he englas #gesceop# , þa| geworhte he þurh his wisdom tyn engla werod on| þam forman dæge on micelre fægernisse , fela þusenda on ðam| frumsceafte , þæt hi on his wuldre hine| wurðedon ealle lichamlease , leohte \& strange , buton eallum| synnum on gesælþe libbende , swa wlitiges| gecindes , swa we secgan ne magon ,
trans: The almighty creator, when he shaped the angels, then through his wisdom on the first day he made ten troops of angels in great beauty, many thousands at the first creation, so that they would worship him in his glory, all of them bodiless, bright and strong, living in joy without all sins, so beautiful of nature that we may not say.

context: \& nan yfel ðing næs on ðam| englum þa git , ne nan yfel ne #com# ðurh| Godes gesceapennisse , for ðan ðe he sylf ys eall god \& ælc| god cimð of him ; \& ða englas þa wunodon| on þam wuldre mid Gode .
trans: And no evil thing was among the angels yet, nor did any evil come through the creation of God, because he himself is all good and every good comes from him, and the angels then lived in glory with God.

context: Hwæt ,| þa binnan six dagum , þe se soða God þa gesceafta| #gesceop# , þe he gescippan wolde , gesceawode| se an engel þe þær ænlicost wæs , hu fæger he silf wæs \&| hu scinende on wuldre , \& cunnode his mihte ,| þæt he mihtig wæs gesceapen , \& him wel gelicode his| wurðfulniss þa : se hatte Lucifer , þæt ys| Leohtberend , for ðære miclan beorhtnisse his mæran hiwes .
trans: Alas, then within six days in which the true God made the creation that he desired to make, the one angel who was the most unique realized how beautiful he was himself and how shining in glory, and he knew his strength and that he was made mighty and he greatly enjoyed his worthiness. His name was Lucifer, that is ‘light-bearing’ for the great brightness of his splendid beauty.

context: ða #þuhte# him to huxlic , þæt he hiran sceolde ænigum| hlaforde , þa he swa ænlic wæs , \& nolde wurðian| þone , þe hine geworhte , \& him þancian æfre ðæs þe he| him forgeaf \& beon him underðeodd þæs ðe| swiþor geornlice for þære micclan mærðe þe he hine| gemæðegode .
trans: Then it seemed him too unseemly that he should obey any lord when he was so unique, and he desired not to worship him who had made him and never thank him for what he had given him, and not to be subject to him because of the great glory with which he had honored him very eagerly.

context: He #nolde# þa habban his Scippend him to hlaforde , ne he nolde| þurhwunian on ðære soþfæstnisse ðæs| soðfæstan Godes sunu , þe hine gesceop fægerne ,| ac wolde mid riccetere him rice gewinnan \& þurh| modignisse hine macian to Gode , \& nam him gegadan ongean Godes| willan to his unræde on eornost gefæstnod .
trans: He desired not to have his Maker as his lord, nor did he desire to continue in faithfulness to the true Son of God, who made him beautiful, but he desired to win for himself a kingdom with power, and desired through pride of mind to make himself God, and secured companions for himself against the will of God, to his folly in eagerness.

context: He #gesette# on his ylde his sunu to cininge , þone snoteran| Salomon , \& he siþþan rixode feowertig| wintra on fulre sibbe æfre , \& for his micclum wisdome hyne| wurðodon ciningas , \& man his wisdom sohte| of fyrlenum eardum , \& of gehwilcum landum him comon lac to| wurðscipe , \& he his folc geheold butan| ælcum gefeohte .
trans: In his old age he set as king his son, the wise Solomon. And he protected his people without any battle.

context: Nabochodonosor , se namcuða cining on Chaldeiscum earde , #com#| to Hierusalem mid micelre fyrde , \& þæt| manncyn ofsloh , \& þa burh towende , \& þæt tempel towearp| æfter feowerhund gearum þæs þe hit gesett| wæs , for ðæra kininga geleafleaste , þe forleton heora| Drihten , \& þæs folces gimeleaste , þe ne gimde| Godes ; \& gelædde þone kining to Chaldea mid him , Achim| gehaten , swiðe huxlice , þæt he mihte| oncnawan his manfullan dæda huru on þam hæftnede wið þone| heofenlican God .

context: Ðas synd þa feower ean of anum wyllspringe , þe #gað# of| Paradisum| ofer Godes folc wide : \& þas feower| godspelleras wæron gefyrn getacnode , swa Ezechiel hi geseah ,| Matheus on mannes hiwe , Marcus on| leon , Lucas on cealfes , Iohannes on earnes , for ðære| getacnunge þe hig getacnodon .
trans: These are the four rivers from one wellspring that go widely out of paradise over the people of God. And these four evangelists were long ago signified as Ezekiel saw them: Matthew in the form of a man, Mark as a lion, Luke as a calf, John as an eagle, because the signs signified them.

context: Matheus #awrat# be Cristes menniscnisse , \& Marcus , swa swa leo| hludswege , clipode on þam wildan| mancynne swilce on westene , \& Lucas be þam sacerde Zacharias| ongann , þe cealf geoffrode on Godes| onsægednisse , and Iohannes , swa swa earn , þa upplican| digolnisse mid his scearpum eagum sceawode georne \&| be Cristes godcundnysse  his godspell| gesette .
trans: Matthew wrote about the humanity of Christ: Mark, like a lion, called out loudly to the untamed humankind in the desert. And John, like an eagle, looked at the high mysteries with his sharp eyes and wrote his gospel about the divinity of Christ.

context: Ðas feower bec #kyþað# hu Crist com to mannum of Marian| ðam mædene , middaneardes alysend on þære| sixtan ylde þissere worulde , be þan ðe þa witegan hit| gewriton on bocum , on Bethleem birig binnan Iudea| on Augustes dagum , þæs æðelan caseres , \& englas þa| kyddon his acennednysse mid heofonlicum sange| fela þusenda .
trans: These four books make known how Christ came to humans through Mary the virgin, the Redeemer of the world, in the sixth age of this world, about which the prophets wrote in books, in the city of Bethlehem within Judea in the days of Augustus the noble emperor, and then many thousands of angels made his birth known with heavenly singing.

context: Eala þu min sunu , hwi flihst| þu þinne fæder ?| Hwi flihst ðu þisne ealdan \& #ungewæpnodan# ?| Ne ondræd þe la earming ; git þu hæfst lifes hiht ․| Ic wille agildan gescead for þinre sawle Criste \& ic lustlice| wille min lif for þe syllan , swa swa| se Hælend sealde hine sylfne for us , \& mine sawle ic sille| for þinre ․| ætstand huru nu , \& gehyr þas word , \& gelyf þæt se Hælend| me asende to þe .
trans: Oh, my son. Why do you flee from your father? Why do you flee from this old and unarmed man? Do not fear, oh wretched one; you still have hope of life. I desire to give an account for your soul to Christ, and I willingly desire to give my life for your soul, just as the Savior gave himself for us, and I would give my soul for yours. Now stand here and hear these words and believe that the Savior sent me to you.

context: þa ætstod se wealdgenga , syþþan he þas word #gehirde# , \&| aleat to eorðan mid eallum lichama , \&| awearp his wæmna \& weop swiðe biterlice , \& he bifiende feoll| to Iohannes fotum mid geomerunge \&| þoterunge mid tearum ofergoten , biddende miltsunge be þam| ðe he mihte , \& behydde his swiðran hand ofsceamod| forðearle for þære morðdæde þe he gedon hæfde , \& for| þam manslihte þe he sloh mid þære handa .

context: He hine #hadode# eac to þæs Hælendes þeowdome ; ac us ne| segð na seo racu to hwam he hine sette , buton| þæt he sealde soðe gebysnunge eallum dædbetendum , þe to| Drihtene gecyrrað , þæt hig magon arisan ,| gif hig rædfæste beoð , fram heora sawle deaþe \& fram heora| synna bendum , \& heora Scippend gladian| mid soðre dædbote , \& habban þæt ece lif mid þam leofan| Hælende se þe a rixað on ecnysse ․| Amen .
trans: He also ordained him to the service of the Savior, but the narrative does not tell us the position to which he appointed him, except that he gave a true example to all the repenting who convert to the Lord, so that if they are wise, they may arise from the death of their souls and from the bonds of their sins and gladden their Maker with true penance and have the eternal life with the beloved Savior, who rules for eternity. Amen.

context: Vespassianus wæs casere on þam timan ; se asende him to his| sunu Titum mid micelre fyrde þæs| Romaniscan folces \& besæt heora burh , oð þæt hi #swulton#| hungre \& mann awearp þa lic for þan laþlican| stence ut ofer ðone weall , \& ne mihton nateshwon for heora| mægenleaste þa meniu bewerian ․

context: Hi cuwon heora girdlas \& gærs #æton# georne , \& ælc læhte of| oðrum , gif he hwæt litles hæfde , \& ðone| mete of þam muðe swiþe unmægðlice , \& reaferas urnon geond| ealle þa burh \& smealice sohton mid| swiþlicum ðreate þone behiddan mete on heora hordcleofan ,| \& beoton ælcne man þe ænig þing hæfde , gif he| heora wodnisse wolde wiðcweðan .
trans: They chewed their belts and eagerly ate grass, and each one took what little others had, and meat from their mouths, very immoderately, and robbers ran through all the city and sharply sought with great threat for hidden food in their treasure chambers, and beat every man who had anything if he would speak against their madness.

context: Nys us na to #secgenne# þone sceamlica| morð þe þær gedon wæs , ac hi wurdon adydde mid þam hatan| hungre , fela hund manna þæs ærman mennisces , ma þonne we| secgan willað , \& þa reaferas siþþan ofsloh ælc| oðerne , \& seo burh wearð gewyld \& toworpen grundlunga , swa| se Hælend sæde ær his þrowunge .

context: Of þam iungum cnihtum , þe #comon# of ðam hungre , on eallum| þam lande hi alæddon aweg to wircenne| godeweb , swa swa hi wæron getogenne , \& of þam cnapum ys| þæt kynn git gehwær , \& þis wæs þæt edlean heora| yfelan dæda \& eac hellewite , þæt þæt him hefegore ys .
trans: Of the young boys who came through the famine in all the land, they led away to make fine linens, just as they were strung along. And from the boys the race is still everywhere, and this was the retribution for their evil deeds, and also the torments of hell, which is heavier on them.

context: Is swa þeah god weorc on þam godan wordum , þonne man| oðerne #lærð# \& to geleafan getrimð mid þære| soþan lare , \& þonne mann wisdom sprecð manegum to þearfe \&| to rihtinge , þæt God si geherod , se þe a rixað ․| Amen .

context: Ac þa halgan fæderas , þe beforan us wæron , swaswa wæs| Sanctus Ieronimus preost and Sanctus Anastasius preost , þe| Sanctus Basilius se biscop #geypte# , and Sanctus Beda preost ,| ðe his ban restað on Eoferwic and ungerime oðre , þe we| heora| naman ne cunnan , geond ealra eorþan ymbhwyrfte| middaneardes hæfden forhæfednesse fram wifes neaweste and| mid ealra gehealdsumnesse and gehyrsumnesse Godes and heora| ealdras Gode wel gecwemdan .
trans: 16a. Aber die heiligen Väter, die vor uns waren, wie der Priester St. Hieronymus und der Priester St. Anastasius, den der Bischof St. Basilius bekannt machte, und der Priester St. Beda, dessen Gebeine in York ruhen und zahllose andere, deren Namen wir nicht kennen, über den ganzen Erdkreis hin, enthielten sich der Nähe des Weibes und in aller Enthaltsamkeit und im Gehorsam gegenüber Gott und ihren Lehrern erwarben sie Gottes Gunst.

context: Nu #gebyrað# mæssepreostum and eallum Godes þeowum , þæt hi| healdan heora cyrcan mid halgum þeowdome ,| And þa seofon tidsangas gesyngon þærinne , þe him gesette| synd , swaswa se sinoð hi gedihte : Uhtsang| and primsang , undernsang and middægsang , nonsang and| æfensang and nihtsang seofoðan .
trans: 48–49. Nun geziemt es sich allen Messepriestern und allen Gottesdienern, dass sie ihre Kirchen in heiliger Dienstbarkeit halten. context: Ac hi misdoð swiðe deope , þæt þæt halige husl #sceole#| fynegian , and nellað understandan , hu mycele dædbote seo| penitentialis tæcð be þam , gyf þæt husel bið| fynig oððe hæwen , oððe gif hit forloren bið , oððe| gif mys þurh gymeleaste hit etað .
trans: 134. Aber sie sündigen schwer, sodass das heilige Abendmahl verderben wird, und sie wollen nicht verstehen, wie groß die Buße sein soll, die die \textit{Penitentialis} ihnen aufträgt, wenn das Abendmahl faul oder unreif ist, oder wenn es verloren geht, oder wenn Mäuse es durch Fahrlässigkeit essen.

Dann trennten sich die Apostel und zogen in ferne Lande, weit in die Welt hinaus, Wunder wirkend und den Glauben verkündigend, und sie tauften die Gläubigen und bauten Kirchen und setzten Bischöfe ein und weihten Messepriester und viele Gottesdiener nach den sieben Weihen, wie uns der Kanon sagt.

context: And he #geendode# swa æmtig on his innoþe , swa he on his| geleafan wæs .
trans: 58. Und er starb mit einem Bauche, der ebenso leer wie sein Glaube war.

context: Oþer sinoð wæs eft , þæt wæs oþer healf hund bisceopa ,| on þeodosiges tyman , þæs , æþelan caseres , and| hy þær fordemdon þone dweligendan bisceop , Macedomum| #gehaten# , and hine amansumedon , forþonþe he wiðsoc and sæde| on his gedwylde , þæt se haliga gast nære on anre| godcundnysse mid þam heofenlican fæder and þam hælende| Criste , and hi getæhtan þa swutelice , þæt he soð God is ,| on anre godcundnysse mid þam ælmihtigan fæder and his| acennedan sunu , æfre wunigende .
trans: 59. Eine zweite Synode fand statt mit anderthalbhundert Bischöfen, (von weither zusammengekommen), zur Zeit des Theodosius, des edeln Kaisers, und diese verdammten dort den ketzterischen Bischof, Macedonius genannt, und sie stießen ihn aus der Gemeinschaft aus, weil er ableugnete und in seiner Ketzerei behauptete, daß der heilige Geist nicht in einer Göttlichkeit mit dem himmlischen Vater und dem Heiland Christ stünde; und sie lehrten da ausdrücklich, daß er wahrer Gott mit dem allmächtigen Vater und seinem geborenen Sohne in einer Göttlichkeit stehend, ewig bleibend, ist.

context: and hi fordemdon þær Nestorium , þone gedwolan ,| þe dyrstelice #cwæð# , þæt on Criste wæron twegen hadas ,
trans: 60. Und sie verdammten dort Nestorius, den Ketzer, der dreist behauptete, dass in Christus zwei Naturen seien.

context: and hi his gedwyld adwæscton þær midealle ,| forþanþe se hælend is soðlice an Crist ,| on anum hade æfre #wunigende# .
trans: 60. Und sie vernichteten dort seine Ketzerei durch und durch, weil der Heiland ein Christus ist, in einer Natur ewig verharrend.

context: Se feorþa sinoð wæs eft ,| þæt wæs syx hund bisceopa and þrittig sacerda on Martianus| tyman , þæs mæran caseres , se fordemde þone deoflican abbod ,| þe #cwæð# on his gedwylde , þæt ures drihtenes lichama and| his godcundnes wære anes gecyndes .
trans: 61. Die vierte Synode fand mit sechshundert Bischöfen und dreißig Priestern statt, zur Zeit des Martianus, des berühmten Kaisers, der den teuflischen Abt verdammte, der in seiner Ketzerei behauptete, dass der Leib unseres Herren und seine Göttlichkeit einer Natur seien.

context: þa #wearð# he amansumod fram þam mycclan sinoþe , forðanþe| se hælend is , swaswa ge gehyrdan oft , soð man and soð God ,| symle wunigende .
trans: 61. Da wurde er durch die große Synode aus der Gemeinschaft verstoßen, weil der Heiland, wie ihr schon oft gehört habt, wahrer Mensch und wahrer Gott ist, ewig bleibend.

trans: 62. Seitdem fanden sehr oft andere Synoden weiser Bischöfe statt, aber dies waren die wichtigsten, die mit voller Lehre den Glauben festigten und die Ketzer verstießen, die mit ihrer Ketzerei Falschheit in Recht verwandelten und das Menschengeschlecht von seinem Herrn ablenken wollten.

context: Be swylcum witegode se witega Isaisas , þus #cweþende# :

context: God soðlice #gecwæð# , swaswa us sæde| se witega : Ic forgife þam clænum , þe gecuran minne wyllan| and min wed healdað and mine restendagas , þa beteran wununge| on minum weallum ; And on minum huse hi habbað wununge , and| hyra nama bið toforan oþrum bearnum ; Ecne naman ic him| forgife .
trans: 88. Gott hat wahrhaftiglich erklärt, wie uns der Prophet gesagt hat: Ich will den Keuschen, die meinen Willen erwählt haben und meinen Bund halten und meine Ruhetage, die besseren Wohnungen in meinen Mauern geben. Und in meinem Hause werden sie Wohnung haben und ihr Name wird von dem der anderen Kinder sein. Einen ewigen Namen werde ich ihnen geben.

context: On þyssum þrym swigenihtum ge #sceolan# singan ætgædere be| fullan eowerne uhtsang , swaswa se antifonere tæcð ․| And feower and twentig candela acwencan æt þam sealmum and| æt ælcere rædingce oþ þone æftemynstan| antifon ․| And geendian þone æftersang swa , þæt ælc singe his pater| noster on sundron and þa preces þærto butan ælcum| leohte licgende on cneowum .
trans: 23–25. An diesen drei stillen Nächten sollt ihr euern Nachtdienst zusammen und vollständig singen, wie das Antiphonar vorschreibt, und beim Singen der Psalmen und bei jeder Lektion bis zur letzten Antiphone vierundzwanzig Kerzen auslöschen, und den Frühgesang so abschließen, dass jeder das \emph{Pater Noster} und die dazu gehörenden Gebete ohne jegliches Licht auf den Knieen liegend singt.

context: Se fifta is Ira , þæt is weamodniss , þæt se mann ne| #mæge# his mod gewildan , ac butan ælcum wisdome waclice| irsað and mannslihtas gefremað and fela reþnissa ․| þone mæg oferswyðan þæs modes geðild , seðe mid gesceade| him sylfan gewissað .

Se eahtoðe heafodleahtor is : cenodoxia , id est , iactantia| uel uana gloria , þæt #is# gylp on englisc| oððe getot , gereht , þæt se mann beo leofgeorn and mid| gylpe afylled , þeahðe he nateshwon hergendlic ne si ․| And byð þonne hiwere þurh þone heafodleahter and ranc on| his gyrelum and unrædfæst on dædum .
trans: 172f. Die achte Todsünde ist: \textit{Cenodoxia, id est iactantia vel vana gloria}, das ist auf Englisch erklärt: Prahlerei oder Ruhmessucht, dass der Mensch lobbegierig ist und mit Prahlerei erfüllt, obgleich er gar nicht lobenswert ist, und dabei zum Heuchler wird durch diese Todsünde und prunkhaft in seinen Kleidern und unklug in seinen Handlungen ist.

context: þis ic #sprece# nu for ðæm þe ic wolde þæt þa ongeaten ,| þe þa tida ures cristendomes leahtriað , hwelc| mildsung siþþan wæs , siþþan se cristendom wæs ; \& hu| monigfeald wolbærnes ðære worulde ær þæm wæs ;| \& eac þæt hie oncnewen hu| gelimplice ure God on þæm ærran| tidum þa anwaldas \& þa ricu sette , se ilca| se þe giet settende is \& wendende ælce onwaldas \& ælc| rice to his willan .

context: æfter þæm þe Romeburg #getimbred# wæs III hund wintra \&| LXXXVIII , þætte Gallie oferhergedan Romana lond| oð IIII mila to ðære byrig , \& þa burg mehton eaðe| begitan gif hie þær ne gewicadon ; for þon Romane| wæron swa forhte \& swa æmode , þæt hie ne wendon þæt| hie þa burg bewerian mehton ․| Ac þæs on morgenne Titus heora ladteow , þe oðre noman wæs| haten Quintius , hie mid firde gesohte .
trans: Three hundred and eighty-eight years after Rome was built, Gauls ravaged the land of the Romans to a point four miles from the city, and could easily have taken the city if they had not slackened off there, since the Romans were so terrified and lacking in courage that they thought that they could not defend the city. But in the morning their leader Titus Quintius advanced against the Gauls with an army.

context: Mid þæm þe þa ærendracan to Rome #comon# , þa com eac mid| him seo ofermæte heardsælnesse \& monegra ðeoda| iermþa , seo longe æfter þæm weaxende wæs , swa hit| heofones tungul on þæm tidun cyþende wæron , þæt| hit wæs niht oð midne dæg , \& on sumre tide hit hagalade| stanum ofer ealle Romane .

context: \& Ocus , Persa cyning , þone mon oþere noman #het# Artecsersis ,| æfter þæm þe he Egyptum forhergede , he| gefor siþþan on Iudana lond , \& hiera fela forhergeade ;| siþþan on Ircaniam þæm londe he heora swiðe| fela gesette wið þone sæ þe mon Caspia hætt , \& hie þær| gesetene sint giet oð þisne dæg mid bradum| folcum , on ðæm tohopan þæt hie sume siðe God þonan ado| to heora agnum lande .
trans: And Ochus the king of Persia, also called Artaxerxes, after ravaging Egypt went to the country of the Jews and ravaged much of that. context: Siþþan þæt gewin angunnen wæs , gif ænig mon sie , cwæð| Orosius , þe on gewritun findan mæge þæt Ianas| dura siþþan belocen #wurde# buton anum geare , \& þæt wæs| for þæm þe Romane eallne þone gear an monncwealme| lægan , ær eft Octauianus dæge þæs caseres .

context: þæt hus hæfdon Romane to ðæm anum tacne #geworht# þæt on| swelce healfe swelce hie þonne winnende beon| woldan , swa suþ , swa norþ , swa east , swa west , þonne| andydan hie þa duru þe on þa healfe open wæs ,| þæt hie be þæm wiston hwider hie sceoldon .

context: þæt eac Octauianus sweotole #getacnade# , þa þa Romane him| woldon ofrian swa heora gewuna wæs , \& sædon| þæt sio sibb of his mihte wære ; ac he ægðer fleah ge þa| dæd ge þa sægene , \& eac self sæde þæt seo| dæd his nære , ne eac beon ne mehte nanes eorðlices monnes ,| þætte ealre worolde| swelce sibbe bringan|  mehte , þætte twa þeoda ær habban ne mehton , ne , ðætte| læsse wæs , twa gemægþa .

context: Raþe æfter þæm on þara twegea consula dæge , Claudius ,| þe oðre noman #hatte# Marcellus , \& Ualerius , þe| oðre noman hatte Flaccus , þa gewearð hit , þeh hit me| scondlic sie , cwæð Orosius , þætte sume Romana| wif on swelcum scinlace wurdon , \& on swelcum wodan dreame ,| þæt hie woldon ælcne mon , ge wif ge wæpned ,| þara þe hie mehton , mid atre acwellan , \& hit on mete| oþþe on drynce to geþicgenne gesellan .
trans: Soon after that in the time of the two consuls Claudius Marcellus and Valerius Flaccus, it came about (though it shames me to say so, said Orosius) that some Roman women got so involved in sorcery and mad frenzy that they wanted to kill everyone they could, women and men, with poison, and to put it into food or drink for them to swallow.

context: His forme gefeoht wæs wið Atheniense , \& hie oferwonn ; \&| æfter þæm wið Hiliricos , þe we Pulgare #hatað# ,| \& heora monig ðusend ofslog , \& heora mæstan| burg geeode ,| Larisan ․| \& siþþan on Thesali he þæt gewinn swiþost dyde for þære| gewilnunge þe he wolde hi him on fultum geteon| for heora wigcræfte , for þon hie cuþon on horsum ealra| folca feohtan betst \& ærest .
trans: His first battle was against the Athenians, and he defeated them. After that he fought against the Illyrians, whom we call Bulgarians, killing many thousands of them and capturing their biggest city, Larissa, and then against the Thessalonians. He pursued that war mainly out of a wish to enlist their forces because of their skill in war, since they knew best and earliest of all peoples how to fight on horseback.

context: Ic #nat# , cwæð Orosius , for hwi eow Romanum sindon þa ærran| gewin swa wel gelicad \& swa lustsumlice on| leoðcwidum to gehieranne , \& for hwy ge þa tida swelcra| broca swa wel hergeað , \& nu , þeh eow lytles| hwæt swelcra gebroca on becume , þonne gemænað ge hit to| þæm wyrrestan tidum , \& magon hie swa hreowlice| wepan swa ge magon þara oþra bliþelice hlihhan .
trans: I don't know why you Romans, said Orosius, take so much pleasure in the old wars and so enjoy hearing about them in poems, and why you praise so extravagantly those times with all these afflictions, and now if you suffer just a little of such troubles then you moan about it as being the worst of times, and can weep over them as miserably as you cheerfully laugh over the others.

context: Ælcum men #gebyrað# , þe ænigne godne cræft hæfð , þæt he| ðone do nytne oðrum mannum and befæste þæt pund ,| þe him god befæste , sumum oðrum men , þæt godes feoh| ne ætlicge and he beo lyðre þeowa gehaten and| beo gebunden and geworpen into ðeostrum , swaswa þæt| halige godspel segð .

context: is nu for ði godes þeowum and mynstermannum georne to| #warnigenne# , þæt seo halige lar on urum dagum| ne acolige oððe ateorige , swaswa hit wæs gedon on| Angelcynne nu for anum feawum gearum , swa þæt nan| englisc preost ne cuðe dihtan oððe asmeagean anne pistol| on leden , oðþæt Dunstan arcebisceop and Aðelwold| bisceop eft þa lare on munuclifum arærdon .

context: Ic #bidde# nu on godes naman , gyf hwa ðas boc awritan wylle ,| þæt he hi gerihte wel be ðære bysne ; forðan| ðe ic nah geweald , þeah hi hwa to woge gebringe þurh| lease writeras , and hit bið ðonne his pleoh , na min .

context: ÆLFRIC #GRET# EADMODLICE ÆÐELWERD EALDORMAN and ic secge þe| leof , þæt ic hæbbe nu gegaderod on þyssere bec þæra| halgena þrowunga þe me to onhagode on englisc to awendene ,

context: þu #wast# leof þæt we awendon on þam twam ærrum bocum| þæra halgena þrowunga and lif , þe angelcynn mid| freolsdagum wurþað .
þu wast leof þæt we awendon on þam twam ærrum bocum| þæra halgena þrowunga and lif , þe angelcynn mid| freolsdagum #wurþað# .

ac we #woldon#| gesettan be sumum þas boc , mannum to getrymminge and to munde| us sylfum , þæt hi us þingion to þam ælmihtigan gode , swa| swa we on worulde heora wundra cyðað .

context: Ic #bidde# nu on Godes naman , gyf hwa ðas boc awritan wille ,| ðæt he hi gerihte wel be ðære bysne ,| for ðan ðe ic nah geweald , ðeah ðe hi hwa to woge| gebringe ðurh lease writeras , \& hit bið ðonne| his pleoh na min :
trans: Ich bitte nun in Gottes Namen, falls jemand dieses Buch abschreiben will, dass er es nach dem Beispiel korrigieren möge, denn ich habe keine Macht darüber, auch wenn es irgendjemand durch schlechte Schreiber zum Schlechten bringt, doch das soll dann seine Schuld sein und nicht meine:

context: micel yfel #deð# se unwritere , gyf he nele his| gewrit gerihtan .
